answers.text: algebra of bounded operators on a Hilbert space that is closed in the weak operator topology and contains the identity operator

qas.question: What does the von Neumann bicommutant theorem show?

answers.text: the analytic definition is equivalent to a purely algebraic definition as an algebra of symmetries.

qas.question: When was direct integral introduced by von Neumann?
What was introduced in von Neumann algebras?

context: Von Neumann introduced the <a3_0>study of rings of operators<a3_0/>, through the von Neumann algebras. A von Neumann algebra is a *-<a0_0>algebra of bounded operators on a Hilbert space that is closed in the weak operator topology and contains the identity operator<a0_0/>. The von Neumann bicommutant theorem shows that <a1_0>the analytic definition is equivalent to a purely algebraic definition as an algebra of symmetries.<a1_0/> The direct integral was introduced in <a2_0>1949<a2_0/> by John von Neumann. One of von Neumann's analyses was to reduce the classification of von Neumann algebras on separable Hilbert spaces to the classification of factors.
